title: The Daily 202: Stacey Abrams isnâ€™t the future of the Democratic Party. Sheâ€™s the present.
authors: ['James Hohmann', 'National Political Correspondent', 'Author Of The Daily', 'January']
text:
Stacey Abrams visits the Grille House restaurant in Albany, Ga., last week. (Melina Mara/The Washington Post)

With Joanie Greve

THE BIG IDEA: Two long years ago, Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi tapped former Kentucky governor Steve Beshear to deliver their partyâ€™s response to President Trumpâ€™s first State of the Union address. He was a 72-year-old white male moderate from a small town at a moment when Democrats were fixated on how they got whupped so badly in rural areas. Bill Clinton carried the Bluegrass State in 1996, but Hillary Clinton garnered less than 33 percent of the vote two decades later. Seated at a table in an old-fashioned diner, Beshear opened with a gaffe. â€œIâ€™m a proud Democrat, but first and foremost, Iâ€™m a proud Republican, and Democrat, and mostly, American,â€ he said.

Chuck and Nancy have picked another Southerner to deliver the 2019 response, but sheâ€™s different in almost every way. And that reflects the mood of the moment in Democratic politics. Stacey Abrams, 45, last year became the first black woman ever nominated by a major party for governor. The former minority leader in the Georgia state House is unapologetically liberal, even though sheâ€™s from a red state. While Beshear went to a state school, Abrams earned her law degree from Yale. Beshear has been married for 50 years and has two grown kids; Abrams, who is single, has never been married and has no children. Heâ€™s mild-mannered; sheâ€™s fiery.

â€œI plan to deliver a vision for prosperity and equality, where everyone in our nation has a voice and where each of those voices is heard,â€ Abrams said in a statement.

-- The shift from Steve to Stacey, with Joe Kennedy III in between, is a nod by party chieftains to what they perceive as growing grass-roots hunger for fresh faces of color who are young and female.

â€œWe were sitting around thinking about this three weeks ago, and her name came up. Immediately, everyone in the room said, â€˜Letâ€™s do it,â€™â€ Schumer (D-N.Y.) told the Atlanta Journal-Constitution. â€œSheâ€™s an amazing person with an amazing story.â€

Pelosi (D-Calif.) said Abrams â€œembodies the American Dream.â€ â€œHer electrifying message of courage, perseverance and hope reinvigorated our nation and our politics, and continues to inspire millions of Americans in every part of the country,â€ the speaker said.

-- Abrams has emerged as an avatar of the resistance movement. â€œAbrams has refused to cede defeat in the governorâ€™s race since ending her campaign on Nov. 17 with a defiant speech blaming her loss on voting irregularities. She received 48.8 percent of the vote to Brian Kempâ€™s 50.2 percent,â€ Vanessa Williams noted in a feature story about her last week. â€œInstead, Abrams announced a new organization, Fair Fight Georgia, focused on battling voter suppression. The group filed a federal lawsuit against state elections officials, alleging that they â€˜grossly mismanagedâ€™ the 2018 election and violated Georgiansâ€™ constitutional and civil rights. State officials have until the end of the month to respond to the suit.â€

-- 2018 was another Year of the Woman, and 2020 may be as well. Exit polls showed a historic gender gap, with women favoring Democrats by 19 points and men favoring Republicans by four points. The first three Democratic senators to launch presidential campaigns are female. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) toppled a white guy who was twice her age, and No. 4 in party leadership, in a Democratic primary last summer. Still only 29, AOC has emerged as the unofficial leader of a freshman class that includes 40 women.

â€œPicking a black woman to deliver this speech is a powerful statement about where the Democratic Party is and where the nation is,â€ Democratic strategist Karine Jean-Pierre told Eugene Scott. â€œThe contrast with Trump could not be more stark.â€

-- One reason Schumer picked Abrams is that he wants her to run for Senate next year against Republican incumbent David Perdue. The minority leader made the case to Abrams during a meeting last month in Washington. If she got in, Democratic odds of winning control of the upper chamber would increase. At the very least, Republicans would be forced to spends tens of millions more to hold the seat than they would otherwise.

Abrams says she will run for office again, but sheâ€™s not sure which one. Sheâ€™s given herself until the end of March to decide about the Senate. If she doesnâ€™t do it, sheâ€™d likely be on shortlists of vice-presidential picks in the summer of 2020. If a Democrat defeats Trump, she could be a prime candidate for a spot in anyoneâ€™s Cabinet in 2021. She could also challenge the governor in a 2022 rematch.

Last week, on MLK day, Abrams launched a statewide tour in Albany, Ga., to thank people who supported her in 2018. A poll released the Friday before last by the Atlanta Journal-Constitution found that 52 percent of registered Georgia voters view her favorably. Kempâ€™s approval rating is only 37 percent.

-- Trump claimed last fall that Abrams was â€œnot qualifiedâ€ to lead a state, even though she has more governing experience than he did when he became president. The president also warned at a pre-election rally in Macon that Georgia would â€œturn into Venezuelaâ€ if she won.

Responding to yesterdayâ€™s announcement, the Republican National Committee called Abrams a loser who is in a â€œnever-ending pursuit of the public limelight.â€ RNC spokeswoman Ellie Hockenbury said in a statement: â€œWhile Chuck Schumer may feel her agenda would be a good fit for national Democrats, itâ€™s worth remembering that it wasnâ€™t even a good fit for her fellow Georgians who rejected her bid for governor just last year.â€

-- Abrams wonâ€™t just be the first black woman to give the official State of the Union response, a tradition that began in 1966. Sheâ€™ll also be the first person to do so who does not currently hold elected office. Vox editor Ezra Klein observes that some of the biggest Democratic stars coming out of 2018 lost their races, including Abrams, Beto Oâ€™Rourke and Andrew Gillum.

What's made it different this year? Is it just where the political talent happened to fall in the election? Or something about how the party and media have changed? â€” Ezra Klein (@ezraklein) January 29, 2019

-- Speaking on the Senate floor yesterday, Schumer also said that he read â€œwith interestâ€ the Daily 202â€™s coverage from the Koch networkâ€™s â€œtouchy-feelyâ€ donor meeting. â€œI hope itâ€™s not sort of just a fig leaf because theyâ€™re getting such bad publicity and America is moving so far away from what they believe,â€ the Democratic leader said.

â€œColor me skeptical,â€ he continued. â€œThe Koch brothers may sit out the presidential contest, as they did in 2016, but their political arm, Americans for Prosperity, continues to support candidates who are divisive, who do not bring us together. Some of the ads you see, the very candidates they support, are dividing us. You canâ€™t on the one hand say you want to bring us together and on the other use your political arm to tear us apart. â€¦ They support the kinds of judges who agree with them on all the corporate stuff, that donâ€™t want regulation and who are against voting rights. How does that bring us together?â€

Koch network spokesman James Davis replies: â€œPeople are tired of the politics of division. We are committed to uniting with anyone to do right, just like we did on criminal justice reform and Right to Try legislation. Letâ€™s come together on a solution for immigration.â€

Welcome to the Daily 202, PowerPost's morning briefing for decision-makers.

Sign up to receive the newsletter.

WHILE YOU WERE SLEEPING:

A tour group from Trinity Presbyterian School in Montgomery, Ala., tours the Lincoln Memorial on Tuesday afternoon. (Jonathan Newton/The Washington Post)

-- The government is operating on a three-hour delay because of the wintry weather. Many of the D.C. regionâ€™s schools are also opening late or closing their doors today. Here is the full list.

-- The wind chill could dip below zero in Washington today. The Capital Weather Gang forecasts: â€œThe truly bitter blast isnâ€™t here quite yet. But itâ€™s still a cold winter day with morning temperatures rising into and through the 20s â€” watch out for icy spots â€” and afternoon highs in the upper 20s to mid-30s. â€¦ Partly sunny morning skies turn mostly cloudy late morning into the afternoon, when a few snow showers could put down a quick coating in spots. â€¦ The bitter cold and dry air pour in as evening temperatures drop like a rock through the 20s and teens. Most spots should see lows in the single digits, maybe all the way down to near zero in our coldest north and west suburbs, and perhaps holding up near 10 degrees downtown.â€

-- Meanwhile, the Midwest is facing a historically cold polar vortex that has already been blamed for one death in Minnesota. Katie Mettler, Christopher Ingraham, Samantha Schmidt and Angela Fritz report: â€œIt has caused statewide declarations of emergency, school closures, Postal Service interruptions and 1,000 airline flight cancellations across the country. Wind chill estimates plummeted to minus-50 in the Dakotas and northern Minnesota on Tuesday morning, and that same, painfully frigid air is forecast to spread southeast into Minneapolis, Milwaukee, Chicago and Detroit. Winds will make it feel like temperatures of minus-30 to minus-40 as far south as Illinois and northern Indiana; it is forecast to feel as low as minus-65 across the northern Great Lakes region.â€

Jussie Smollett, a cast member in â€œEmpire,â€ was attacked in a potential hate crime in Chicago. (Evan Agostini/Invision/AP)

GET SMART FAST:â€‹â€‹

â€œEmpireâ€ actor Jussie Smollett was assaulted in Chicago in an attack that police are investigating as a â€œpossible racially charged assault and battery.â€ The Chicago Police Department said in a statement that Smollett, who is black and openly gay, was confronted by â€œtwo unknown offenders [who] approached him and gained his attention by yelling out racial and homophobic slurs towards him.â€ The attackers poured an â€œunknown chemical substanceâ€ on Smollett and at one point wrapped a noose around his neck. (Travis M. Andrews and Bethonie Butler) The Pittsburgh shooting suspect is facing additional hate-crime charges. In its updated indictment, the Justice Department detailed anti-Semitic comments Robert Bowers allegedly made in the run-up to the attack. (Devlin Barrett) The FBI said Las Vegas shooter Stephen Paddock was not driven by any â€œsingle or clear motivating factor.â€ Neither the bureau nor local police could determine a precise motive for the devastating attack that left 58 people dead. (Mark Berman) Eric Schneiderman used nearly $340,000 in campaign funds to pay his legal fees as the former New York attorney general confronted allegations of physical abuse. The practice is legal but largely frowned upon by campaign-finance interest groups, and one of Schneidermanâ€™s accusers expressed outrage that he was not forced to pay the bills out of his own pocket. (AP) Rep. Gwen Moore (D-Wis.) announced that she has been battling cancer for nearly a year and is now in remission. â€œThis is a cancer I will live with for the rest of my life, but, because of my high-quality healthcare and insurance coverage, it is not a cancer I will die from,â€ Moore said of her small-cell lymphoma. (Felicia Sonmez) Tesla CEO Elon Musk flew more than 150,000 miles last year on a private jet, travel that was largely paid for by the struggling car company. Tesla has laid off thousands of employees in the past year as Muskâ€™s corporate jet logged more than 250 flights. (Drew Harwell) A woman in New York died after she fell while trying to carry her daughterâ€™s stroller down the steps at a subway station. The death of Malaysia Goodson has highlighted the accessibility issues of the transit system. Her 1-year-old daughter Rhylee survived the fall. (New York Times)

CARACAS ON THE BRINK:

-- Venezuelan authorities froze the bank accounts of self-declared interim president Juan GuaidÃ³ and sought to block him from leaving the country as President NicolÃ¡s Maduro tries to quash the most legitimate threat yet to his power. Andreina Aponte, Rachelle Krygier and Anthony Faiola report: â€œMaduroâ€™s chief prosecutor made the request, which was later ratified by the loyalist Supreme Court as a preventative measure pending a full investigation. The move stopped short of a detention order â€” something the Trump administration has strongly warned against. â€¦ Speaking at the opposition-led National Assembly, which he heads, GuaidÃ³ responded to the move by dismissing it as â€˜nothing new under the sun.â€™ He said it came from â€˜a regime that doesnâ€™t give answers to Venezuelansâ€™ and whose â€˜only answer is persecution and repression.â€™ GuaidÃ³ added: â€˜The world is clear on whatâ€™s happening in Venezuela. â€¦ Letâ€™s not desist because of threats and persecution.â€™

â€œThe United States, which backs GuaidÃ³ as the legitimate leader of Venezuela, pushed back hard against the chief prosecutorâ€™s effort. â€˜We denounce the illegitimate former Venezuelan Attorney Generalâ€™s threats against President Juan Guaido,â€™ White House national security adviser John Bolton wrote on Twitter. â€˜Let me reiterateâ€”there will be serious consequences for those who attempt to subvert democracy and harm Guaido.â€™â€

-- Trump tweeted this morning: â€œAmericans should not travel to Venezuela until further notice.â€

-- Maduro is attempting to clamp down on the opposition by unleashing increasingly aggressive police tactics against dissidents. Mariana ZuÃ±iga and Anthony Faiola report: â€œAs the opposition campaign to oust him dramatically escalated, the warren-like streets of the Puerta Caracas slum filled with pot-banging, anti-government demonstrators. A culture center run by Maduro loyalists was burned down. Hungry, beaten-down residents felt a rush of hope. Then night fell, along with the boot steps of government forces. Maduro called the arsonists 'fascist criminals,' and residents in the western Caracas enclave paid the price. Mask-wearing special forces, locals said, swarmed the neighborhood last week, kicking in doors, rounding up young people and imposing an effective curfew. â€¦ Over the past week, similar operations have extended to at least five other rebellious slums across the capital, leaving 35 people dead â€” including victims as young as 16 â€” and more than 850 arrested.â€

-- Critics of the Trump White House say Boltonâ€™s display of a note indicating the possible deployment of U.S. troops to Colombia is indicative of the administrationâ€™s careless handling of sensitive matters. From David Nakamura: â€œRevealing private notes, including [President George W.] Bushâ€™s request for a â€˜bathroom breakâ€™ at the United Nations in 2005, have bedeviled past presidents â€” but rarely with the frequency of the Trump White House. Obamaâ€™s White House photographer, Pete Souza, occasionally posted photos of marked-up presidential addresses, but those were carefully curated to cast the president as a thoughtful writer and editor. Boltonâ€™s appearance in the briefing room â€” just days after photographers snapped senior aide Stephen Millerâ€™s notes, including the underlined term â€˜Radical Democrats,â€™ during a White House meeting â€” was something of a flashback to the earliest days of the administration.â€

Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov meets with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Pyongyang. (Valery Sharifulin/AFP/Getty Images)

THEREâ€™S A BEAR IN THE WOODS:

-- Russia attempted to interfere last year in U.S.-North Korean nuclear negotiations by offering Pyongyang a nuclear power plant in exchange for destroying its nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles. John Hudson and Ellen Nakashima report: â€œThe Russian offer, which intelligence officials became aware of in late 2018, marked a new attempt by Moscow to intervene in the high-stakes nuclear talks as it reasserts itself in a string of geopolitical flash points from the Middle East to South Asia to Latin America. Itâ€™s unclear how [Trump] will view Moscowâ€™s proposal. For months, he has embraced an unorthodox approach to the negotiations, but his aides are likely to strenuously oppose any major Russian role in a final agreement.â€

-- Trump spoke to Vladimir Putin for several minutes during Novemberâ€™s G-20 summit without a note-taker or translator from the U.S. side, according to the Financial Timesâ€™s James Politi, Demetri Sevastopulo and Henry Foy. â€œThe discussions between the US and Russian presidents occurred at the 19th-century ColÃ³n theatre in the Argentine capital, as world leaders and their spouses or guests were streaming out of the building. Mr Trump was accompanied by Melania Trump, his wife, but no staff, while Mr Putin was flanked by his translator. The four of them sat at a table and were among the last to leave. â€¦ Mr Trumpâ€™s aides characterised the Putin encounter as one of several â€˜informalâ€™ conversations that Mr Trump had with his counterparts that evening.

â€œThe accounts of people familiar with the conversation said it appeared longer and more substantive than the White House has acknowledged. According to a Russian government officialâ€™s account, the two leaders spoke for about 15 minutes about a number of foreign policy issues, including the Azov Sea incident and the conflict in Syria. They also discussed when they could have a formal meeting, the official said. Mr Trump explained that a full meeting with Mr Putin was impossible at the time, and the Russian leader responded by saying he â€˜was not in a hurryâ€™ and remained ready to meet when it suited Mr Trump best, the Russian official said.â€

-- Moscow is advancing a plan to stop punishing officials for â€œunavoidableâ€ bribes. The Moscow Times reports: â€œPutin proposed the measure in an anti-corruption plan signed in June 2018 that called for legislation that would allow officials to escape prosecution for corruption under â€˜exceptional circumstances.â€™ â€¦ The amendments drafted by the Justice Ministry seek to exempt officials from legal accountability when corruption is unavoidable. â€˜In certain circumstances, complying with restrictions and bans ... to prevent or settle conflicts of interests â€¦ is impossible for objective reasons,â€™ the draft bill on the government's legal portal says.â€

-- Split-screen: Leaders of the intelligence community, all appointed by Trump, said Russia and China represent two of the most significant national security threats during Senate testimony in which they repeatedly offered assessments starkly at odds with the presidentâ€™s public posturing. Shane Harris reports: â€œThe two U.S. adversaries â€˜are more aligned than at any point since the mid-1950s,â€™ Director of National Intelligence Daniel Coats said in his prepared remarks before the Senate Intelligence Committee. ... The countries have expanded cooperation in the energy sector over the past half decade; influenced international bodies that set rules and standards, particularly around communications technology; and will collaborate on the shared goal of â€˜taking advantage of rising doubts in some places about the liberal democratic model,â€™ Coats warned. CIA Director Gina Haspel, FBI Director Christopher A. Wray and other top officials joined Coats.â€ (They were there to discuss the new National Intelligence Strategy, which I wrote about last week.)

-- Here are five of the main issues where the intelligence community leaders broke with Trump:

Coats â€œsaid that North Korea was â€˜unlikely to completely give up its nuclear weapons and production capabilities,â€™ which the countryâ€™s leaders consider â€˜critical to the regimeâ€™s survival.â€™ That assessment threw cold water on the White Houseâ€™s more optimistic view that the United States and North Korea will achieve a lasting peace and that the regime will ultimately give up its nuclear weapons.â€™â€ â€œNone of the officials said there is a security crisis at the U.S.-Mexico border, where Trump has considered declaring a national emergency so that he can build a wall.â€ â€œOfficials also warned that the Islamic State was capable of attacking the United States and painted a picture of a still-formidable organization. Trump has declared the group defeated and has said he wants to withdraw U.S. troops from Syria as a result.â€ â€œThe officials assessed that the government of Iran was not trying to build a nuclear weapon, despite the Trump administrationâ€™s persistent claims that the country has been violating the terms of an international agreement forged during the Obama administration. Officials told lawmakers that Iran was in compliance with the agreement.â€ â€œOfficials also warned, as they did last year, about Russiaâ€™s intention to interfere with the U.S. political system. â€¦ Trump continues to equivocate on whether Russia interfered in the 2016 election on his behalf, contradicting the unanimous assessment of all the top intelligence officials currently serving.â€

-- â€œThe disconnect between [Trump] and the Republican establishment on foreign policy has rarely been as stark,â€ the New York Timesâ€™s Peter Baker notes. â€œIn recent days, the presidentâ€™s own advisers and allies have been pushing back, challenging his view of the world and his prescription for its problems. The growing discontent among Republican national security hawks was most evident on Tuesday when [Mitch McConnell] effectively rebuked the president by introducing a measure denouncing â€˜a precipitous withdrawalâ€™ of American troops from Syria and Afghanistan.â€

THE INVESTIGATIONS:

-- Roger Stone pleaded not guilty to the charges laid out by special counsel Bob Mueller. Spencer S. Hsu, Ann E. Marimow and Devlin Barrett report: â€œHe faces charges of lying, obstruction and witness tampering. Asked Tuesday whether he would consider pardoning Stone, [Trump] told The Washington Post, â€˜I have not given it any thought.â€™ â€¦ As Stone walked into the courthouse Tuesday morning, some onlookers chanted â€˜lock him up!â€™ while others screamed their support for him and the president. After he went inside the courthouse, some of those people engaged in profanity-laced arguments about the case. â€¦ In the courtroom Tuesday, prosecutors said the Stone case would be tried jointly by Muellerâ€™s office and the U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia and asked for no change to the terms of Stoneâ€™s release set by a Florida judge Friday. â€¦ The judge agreed with those conditions and scheduled the next court hearing for Feb. 1.â€

-- The Senate Judiciary Committeeâ€™s planned vote on William Barrâ€™s nomination as attorney general was delayed amid Democratic concerns about how he would handle the Mueller probe. Karoun Demirjian reports: â€œThe delay, which is customary for high-profile nominations, is not expected to impede Barrâ€™s chances of being confirmed by the full Senate. But it is the latest reflection of the deep partisan tension surrounding Barrâ€™s nomination, most of which centers on Democratsâ€™ desire to protect Muellerâ€™s probe from being unduly constrained. The committee was scheduled to vote on 46 nominations on Tuesday, including Barrâ€™s, but decided to delay until Feb. 7.â€

-- House Democrats raised concerns about a potential conflict of interest in Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchinâ€™s decision to lift sanctions on the businesses of Russian oligarch Oleg Deripaska. The New York Timesâ€™s Kenneth P. Vogel reports: â€œIn a letter to Mr. Mnuchin, two senior Democratic lawmakers said the Treasury secretaryâ€™s connection to an entertainment business owned in part by [a billionaire Republican] donor, Len Blavatnik, a major investor in Mr. Deripaskaâ€™s giant aluminum company, Rusal, was a potential conflict of interest. â€¦ Tony Sayegh, the Treasury Departmentâ€™s assistant secretary for public affairs, said that Mr. Mnuchin had â€˜no business relationshipâ€™ with Mr. Blavatnik and that any implication of a conflict of interest or ethical problem was â€˜absurd.â€™â€

-- The Justice Department's inspector general wants to investigate Labor Secretary Alexander Acostaâ€™s role in securing a cushy plea deal for alleged serial sex offender Jeffrey Epstein while Acosta was serving as a federal prosecutor in Florida. But he's currently barred from doing so. Bloomberg Lawâ€™s Chris Opfer and Jaclyn Diaz report: â€œâ€˜Your letter raises important questions about the resolution of this case by department attorneys,â€™ DOJ Inspector General Michael Horowitz said in a Jan. 29 letter to lawmakers. â€˜However, the OIG does not currently have jurisdiction over matters involving allegations of misconduct relating to DOJ attorneysâ€™ handling of litigation or legal decisions.â€™ â€¦ Horowitz called on the Senate to take up a bill (H.R. 202) recently passed by the House. He said that legislation would give him the authority to investigate alleged prosecutorial misconduct.â€

-- The first meeting of the new House Oversight Committee, which will oversee investigations of the Trump administration, featured fireworks between Freedom Caucus Chairman Mark Meadows (R-N.C.) and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.). Bloomberg Newsâ€™s Billy House reports: â€œMeadows and other Republicans were telling Chairman Elijah Cummings of Maryland that members should get more than three daysâ€™ notice to attend questioning of witnesses by Democratic staff lawyers. Meadows said five days was better, particularly for lawmakers who live far from Washington. Ocasio-Cortez wasted no time in offering her first remarks on the committee. â€˜I donâ€™t believe we need five daysâ€™ if lawmakers are doing their jobs, she responded. Meadows wasnâ€™t going to let that go. Formally directing his remarks to Cummings, he responded: â€˜Mr. Chairman, I can tell you on all of this at this particular point, weâ€™re all wanting to cooperate.â€™ But he said, â€˜Sometimes our schedules, you know, weâ€™re not just sitting around eating bonbons, waiting for the call of anybody.â€™ Ocasio-Cortez then asked Cummings whether Republicans gave members ample notice for such matters during the last congressional session, when they ran the committee. â€˜No,â€™ said Cummings, of Maryland. â€˜OK, thank you,â€™ said Ocasio-Cortez.â€

THE IMMIGRATION WARS:

-- The Trump Organization plans to verify employeesâ€™ immigration status following a Post report that one of the presidentâ€™s golf clubs hired undocumented immigrants for years. Jonathan O'Connell, Elise Viebeck and Tracy Jan report: â€œâ€˜We are instituting E-Verify on all of our properties as soon as possible,â€™ Eric Trump, one of the presidentâ€™s sons and executive vice president of the Trump Organization, said Tuesday, acknowledging that the company currently uses the program only at some locations. â€¦ The move is the first acknowledgment by the presidentâ€™s private business that it has failed to fully check the work status of all its employees, despite Trumpâ€™s claims during the 2016 campaign that he used E-Verify across his properties. At the time, he called for the program to be mandatory for all employers. The decision by the Trump Organization is not likely to head off calls for an investigation by congressional Democrats, who on Tuesday began gathering signatures for a letter to FBI Director [Wray] seeking a probe into whether the presidentâ€™s company broke the law by hiring undocumented workers.â€

-- The United States started instituting its new policy of forcing asylum seekers at the southern border to wait in Mexico as their cases are processed. Maya Averbuch and Kevin Sieff report: â€œHomeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen planned to visit the San Ysidro port of entry later in the day to â€˜assess implementationâ€™ of the new approach, according to a DHS statement. â€¦ The return of [a] Honduran asylum seeker Tuesday appeared to be ad hoc; he was rushed to a van by a Mexican immigration agent with no formal announcement of when Â­others would follow. Rodulfo Figueroa, the national migration agencyâ€™s representative in Tijuana, said no others would be released Tuesday.â€

-- The Pentagon intends to send thousands more U.S. troops to the southern border. Dan Lamothe reports: â€œActing defense secretary Patrick M. Shanahan told reporters at the Pentagon that the evolving mission will focus heavily on watching the border for potential threats. It will mark the latest shift in how active-duty troops are used on the border, and nudge the number from about 2,300 active-duty service members closer to a high-water mark of about 5,900 that were involved in November. An additional 2,300 national guardsmen also are deployed to the border mission.â€

-- Following the shutdown, Democrats have taken a rare polling lead over Trump on border security. From Aaron Blake: â€œA new Quinnipiac University poll finds Americans trust Democrats more than Trump on border security, 50 percent to 41 percent. That is up from a 49-to-44 Democratic advantage two weeks ago. Both findings are rare since the issue has almost always favored the GOP. As recently as November, a Washington Post-ABC News poll found people favored Republicans to Democrats on the issue of border security by nearly the opposite margin, 49 to 39.â€

A SECOND SHUTDOWN?

-- Republican lawmakers proposed a debt-ceiling increase as one component of a possible deal in their frantic efforts to avoid another government shutdown. Robert Costa and Erica Werner report: â€œThe latest idea to tack on an increase in the nationâ€™s borrowing limit to discussions over Trumpâ€™s demand for $5.7 billion for a U.S.-Mexico border wall divided Republicans and was immediately rejected by Democrats, a less-than-promising development on the eve of congressional negotiatorsâ€™ first meeting. â€˜I donâ€™t want to sink the whole thing,â€™ Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R-Alaska) said when asked about the flurry of proposals by her colleagues. Still, Sen. Lindsey O. Graham (R-S.C.), a Trump ally, and others worked to nudge a bipartisan group of lawmakers toward including a debt-limit hike, hoping to avoid another shutdown in mid-February when funding expires as well as a market-rattling showdown over the nationâ€™s debt. â€¦

â€œMost Republicans are now eager to avoid another shutdown, due to the political fallout they have endured in polls, which show a majority of Americans blaming Trump and the GOP for the standoff. [Mitch McConnell], who has been cautious, said Tuesday, â€˜Iâ€™m for whatever works, which means avoiding a shutdown and avoiding the president feeling he should declare a national emergency.â€™ â€¦ The suggestions â€” which also included spending restrictions and protections for young undocumented immigrants as part of a broader pact â€” complicated the path ahead for the committee of 17 lawmakers charged with coming up with a spending deal to stave off another shutdown Feb. 15.â€

-- The lowest-paid government contractors are still feeling the impact of the first shutdown. Danielle Paquette reports: â€œUnlike the 800,000 career public servants who are slated to receive full back pay over the next week or so, the contractors who clean, guard, cook and shoulder other jobs at federal workplaces arenâ€™t legally guaranteed a single penny. Theyâ€™re also among the lowest-paid laborers in the government economy, generally earning between $450 and $650 weekly, union leaders say. â€¦ HÃ©ctor Figueroa, president of 32BJ SEIU, a labor union that represents 170,000 service workers on the East Coast, said reopening the government is a temporary fix for people on such shaky ground.â€

-- Officials at Mount Rainier National Park worked to cut through five weeksâ€™ worth of snow that built up during the shutdown. Lornet Turnbull reports: â€œItâ€™s likely to take at least two days to clear, leaving huge snowbanks around the perimeter. Road crews and other staff members at Mount Rainier National Park are scrambling to reopen this iconic volcanic mountain to the public, more than a month after the partial federal government shutdown cut off official access to some of its most popular wintertime activities. The park lost 10 percent of its working year, Superintendent Chip Jenkins laments. And while Paradise might begin welcoming visitors by next weekend, there is bigger concern about the long-term effect those lost days could have on the crucial summer season.â€

Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti speaks during a news conference in Los Angeles. (Jae C. Hong/AP)

2020 WATCH:

-- Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti announced that he would not seek the Democratic presidential nomination. The LA Timesâ€™s Michael Finnegan and Dakota Smith report: â€œAfter nearly two years of flirting with the idea that he could leap from City Hall to the worldâ€™s most powerful job, the mild-mannered mayor reached a decision in keeping with his reputation for avoiding political risk. He also passed up a chance to run for governor last year when the odds seemed stacked against him. At a City Hall news conference, Garcetti said he decided over the last couple of weeks to stay put as mayor because he â€˜realized that this is what I am meant to do and this is where I want to be.â€™â€

-- One possible beneficiary of Garcettiâ€™s decision: Sen. Kamala Harris, who may now become the only high-profile presidential candidate from California. From the San Francisco Chronicleâ€™s Joe Garofoli: â€œSince Californiaâ€™s primary will be held on March 3, 2020 â€” far earlier in than in many past election cycles â€” it could have an outsized impact on whom the partyâ€™s nominee will be. â€˜Itâ€™s always easy to be the favorite daughter when thereâ€™s no favorite son,â€™ said Thad Kousser, a professor of political science at UC San Diego and author of â€˜The New Political Geography of California.â€™ â€˜If I were Kamala, Iâ€™d be giddy,â€™ said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, a retired professor of public policy communication at the University of Southern California. Among other things, â€˜Harris and Garcetti were hitting a lot of the same Democratic donors,â€™ she said.â€

-- Harrisâ€™s acknowledgement that Medicare-for-all would also mean private insurance for none underscores the risks for 2020 Democrats who have chosen to embrace it. Annie Linskey reports on the fallout: â€œIn a single flourish, Harris drew attention to the fact that the Medicare-for-all plans backed by 16 senators â€” including five potential candidates for the Democratic nomination â€” would in effect remove private health insurance from the estimated 251 million Americans who use it, broadly disrupting the industry and the way Americans experience the medical system. â€¦

â€œCandidates can point to evidence that thereâ€™s popular support for the idea. Fifty-six percent of respondents backed a Medicare-for-all plan, according to a recent Kaiser Family Foundation survey. â€¦ But enthusiasm for the idea plummets when respondents are told the plan would largely eliminate private health insurance companies: Only 37 percent favor eliminating private insurance. And nearly 70 percent of those surveyed in a Gallup report released in December said they think their health coverage is either â€˜goodâ€™ or â€˜excellent.â€™â€

-- Harrisâ€™s team tried to clean up the senator's comments. CNNâ€™s Gregory Krieg, Tami Luhby and Maeve Reston report: â€œA Harris adviser on Tuesday signaled that the candidate would also be open to the more moderate health reform plans, which would preserve the industry, being floated by other congressional Democrats ... Both the adviser and Harris national press secretary Ian Sams said her willingness to consider alternate routes to a single payer system should not cast doubt on her commitment to the policy.â€

-- â€œThe unique harm we cause when we dissect a powerful womanâ€™s love life,â€ by Monica Hesse: â€œThe candidate in question [Harris], whose past relationship with former San Francisco mayor Willie Brown was confirmed for the national media when Brown published an op-ed: Yes, theyâ€™d dated. And, yes, he â€˜may have influenced her careerâ€™ by appointing her to two commissions. â€¦ The two things were separate, according to Brown. 1) They dated. 2) He helped her career. The latter didnâ€™t have anything to do with the former. Whether you believe that probably depends on whether you believe one can separate someoneâ€™s professional qualifications from their dinner companionship. â€¦ [I]tâ€™s not that we donâ€™t talk about the sexual predilections of male candidates. But we do talk about them in a different way. We talk about men abusing power. We talk about women not even deserving power. The distinction matters, because the conversation isnâ€™t really about sex, itâ€™s about legitimacy.â€

Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (D-Hawaii) greets supporters in Honolulu. (Marco Garcia/AP)

-- Rep. Tulsi Gabbardâ€™s presidential campaign has already spiraled out of control, and the vanity project now threatens to cost the Hawaii Democrat her House seat. Politicoâ€™s Daniel Strauss and Alex Thompson report: â€œTwo-and-a-half weeks after she told CNN she had decided to run for the White Houseâ€”an announcement that even her own staff didn't know was coming, after weeks of debating the timing of the rolloutâ€”the 37-year-old congresswoman has struggled to contain the chaos. Campaign manager Rania Batrice and Gabbardâ€™s consulting firm Revolution Messaging are set to depart after this weekendâ€™s official kickoff in Hawaii â€¦ Meanwhile, the congresswoman is under fire back home after picking a fight with Sen. Mazie Hirono (D), and a prominent Democratic state lawmaker is already challenging Gabbard in next yearâ€™s congressional primary. That means she faces the possibility of losing the presidential race and her House seat as well.â€

-- Howard Schultz is facing intense blowback over his potential independent presidential campaign. But the former Starbucks CEO has spent months preparing the unconventional bid. Michael Scherer reports: â€œ[Schultz deployed] more than six national polls and [laid] the groundwork for paid advertising that could debut in the next two months. The full reach of the project suggests that his stated goal of disrupting the U.S. political process is not likely to fade away anytime soon, despite enormous historical barriers to success and Democratic predictions that his entry in the race will help [Trump] get reelected. An early advertising effort, made possible by Schultzâ€™s net worth of about $3.4 billion, would be designed to help Schultz show early promise in national polls during his book tour, which he has described as a time to test the appeal of his ideas.â€

-- Schultz further attracted Democratic ire by belittling the policy positions of Elizabeth Warren, Harris and Ocasio-Cortez. John Wagner reports: â€œDuring an interview Tuesday on NPRâ€™s â€˜Morning Edition,â€™ Schultz, a billionaire, said that Warrenâ€™s plan for a special 2 percent annual tax on Americans whose net worth exceeds $50 million is â€˜ridiculous.â€™ â€¦ The exchange came just a few hours after Schultz called Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) â€˜a bit misinformedâ€™ and pushed back on her idea of a top marginal tax rate of 70 percent. â€¦ Schultz also knocked the views of a policy adviser to Ocasio-Cortez as â€˜un-American.â€™â€ Schultz also referred to Harrisâ€™s comments on â€œMedicare-for-allâ€ as â€œnot American.â€

-- Former senator Jeff Flake ruled out a possible primary challenge against Trump in 2020. â€œI have always said that I do hope that there is a Republican who challenges the president in the primary,â€ Flake told â€œCBS This Morning.â€ â€œI still hope that somebody does, but that somebody wonâ€™t be me. I will not be a candidate.â€ (John Wagner)

Cliff Sims, then director of White House Message Strategy, stands with Kellyanne Conway and Sean Spicer as they listen to President Trump speak on the South Lawn in June 2017. (Pablo Martinez Monsivais/AP)

WEST WING INTRIGUE:

-- Trump lashed out against former White House aide Cliff Sims and may have inadvertently helped sell more copies of Simsâ€™s new book. CNNâ€™s Brian Stelter reports: â€œâ€˜A low level staffer that I hardly knew named Cliff Sims wrote yet another boring book based on made up stories and fiction,â€™ Trump said in his tweet. â€¦ At the time of the Tuesday morning tweet, â€˜Team of Vipersâ€™ was No. 12 on Amazon's best selling books list. The rankings are updated every hour. â€˜Vipersâ€™ has been moving up the list ever since, and as of Tuesday afternoon, it stands at No. 6. Of course, it's impossible to know how much of the sales momentum is due to Trump, and how much is due to other factors like Sims' TV appearances. â€¦ But Trump's post triggered a brand new news cycle about Sims' depictions of a distracted president and a distrustful inner circle of aides.â€

-- Sims pushed back against claims he was fired from his role. The New York Timesâ€™s Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman report: â€œAnticipating pushback from the White House, he told George Stephanopoulos, the host [of â€˜Good Morning Americaâ€™], that he had brought his resignation letter along to prove it. White House aides have been telling reporters for weeks that Mr. Sims was fired, but did not want to comment about him on the record. A former official noted that Mr. Sims was â€˜instructed to leave due to a major security breachâ€™ â€” a reference to what Mr. Sims said was the time he recorded [Trump] in the White House on his government phone and then emailed those files to himself, but insisted that was not the reason he left.â€

-- In an interview with the New Yorker, Sims said he was still â€œproudâ€ of working for the Trump administration and seemed largely unfazed by Trumpâ€™s most controversial positions. Of birtherism, Sims said, â€œI think thatâ€™s, like, a great example of a time where he does not step up to the plate and take on these race issues in an appropriate way, a helpful way for the country.â€ When asked whether he would have left the administration during the implementation of migrant family separations, Sims replied, â€œI donâ€™t know. Maybe. Maybe.â€ He added when discussing the Charlottesville fallout, â€œI really donâ€™t think there is a racist bone in [Trumpâ€™s] body.â€ (New Yorker)

-- Chris Christie, who is on his own book tour, described Jared Kushner as the most influential person in the White House. â€œHe's not the only person who [Trump] listens to, but I don't think anyone has more influence than Jared has,â€ the former New Jersey governor told NPR.

title: Empire cast member alleges racial and homophobic attack
text:
A cast member on the hit television show Empire alleged he was physically attacked by men in Chicago who shouted racial and homophobic slurs, police said Tuesday.

Police did not release the actorâ€™s name but a statement from Fox, which airs Empire, identified him as Jussie Smollett, 36. Authorities said they are investigating the alleged attack as a hate crime. Smollett is black and openly gay.

According to a police statement, the actor was walking near the Chicago River downtown around 2 a.m. Tuesday when he was approached by two men who shouted at him, struck him in the face and poured an â€œunknown substanceâ€ on him before one of them wrapped a rope around his neck.

Police spokesman Anthony Guglielmi said that when officers first came in contact with Smollett, he still had a rope around his neck. While being interviewed by detectives, Guglielmi said Smollett told them that the attackers yelled he was in â€œMAGA country,â€ an apparent reference to the Trump campaignâ€™s â€œMake America Great Againâ€ slogan that some critics of the president have decried as racist and discriminatory.

The police spokesman added that the two men were wearing masks. Investigators have not found any surveillance video or witnesses from which they can put together a description of the offenders, he said.

Smollett was able to take himself to Northwestern Memorial Hospital. He was last reported in good condition.

Guglielmi also said the FBI is investigating a threatening letter targeting Smollett that was sent to the Fox studio in Chicago last week.

Twentieth Century Fox Television and Fox Entertainment released a statement Tuesday in support of Smollett. â€œThe entire studio, network and production stands united in the face of any despicable act of violence,â€ the statement read. Empire co-creator Lee Daniels also voiced his support for Smollett in an Instagram video: â€œYou didnâ€™t deserve, nor anybody deserves, to have a noose put around your neck. You are better than that, we are better than that, America is better than that.â€

title: The Manure-Spreaders of Media Sensationalism
text:
Michelle Malkin

The Manure-Spreaders of Media Sensationalism

Here we go again. If you think the manure-spreaders of sensationalism who masquerade as ethical practitioners of journalism learned anything from last week's MAGA-bashing Covington Catholic High School hoax, I have three words for you:

Ha, ha, ha.

On Tuesday morning, uncorroborated claims by actor Jussie Smollett that he was the victim of a "brutal" hate crime by Trump supporters in Chicago went viral across social media. Entertainment rag TMZ.com first splashed "exclusive" headlines that the "Empire" cast member was "beaten by MAGA backers" in a "homophobic attack" at around 2 a.m. in Chicago. If you have no idea what "Empire" is or who Smollett is, join the club. The TV star is apparently a vocal critic of Trump and attacked "45 and all his white hooded cohorts" on Instagram last week.

But I digress.

Within minutes, the gossip site's squib on the TV star's alleged victimization trended on Twitter and rocketed up to USA Today, Variety, CBS, CNN and The New York Times. The Fishwrap of Record breathlessly reported lurid details of two people who "wrapped rope around his neck," which multiple outlets characterized as a "noose." A police statement providing incident background stated that "the offenders began to batter the victim with their hands about the face and poured an unknown chemical substance on the victim," according to Smollett. Multiple websites reported that the substance was bleach.

This is truly horrible, if true. But color me cautious and skeptical. TMZ initially reported that Smollett had exited a Subway chain restaurant near his luxury apartment when accosted by the racist, homophobic assailants, who allegedly recognized him from his work on "Empire." Allegedly, Smollett received a hate mail with the word "MAGA" on it addressed to him and sent to his studio in Chicago last week. If this was a premeditated attack, the FBI should get to the bottom of it.

But oddities and discrepancies abound:

TMZ quoted one of the "MAGA country" attackers who allegedly hurled epithets at Smollett: "Aren't you that f----t 'Empire' n-----?"

Question: How many racist homophobic menaces wander around the upscale Streeterville neighborhood of liberal Chicago at 2 a.m. carrying rope and bleach, yelling about "MAGA country"?

Question: How many racist homophobic menaces have ever heard of "Empire," could recognize Jussie Smollett, or know or care anything about his sexuality?

Despite TMZ's claim that Smollett had the "hell beat outta him" and attackers "broke his ribs" plus subjected him to a chemical attack, an ambulance was not called and he instead "self-transported" to the hospital. CWB Chicago, a local public safety watchdog site, reported on police dispatch records documenting that Smollett's friend "Frank" refused EMS services for Smollett; no mention of bleach was made; "no or minor injury" was observed; and "officers never sent a 'flash; message with offender descriptions to field units."

Weird.

Another assertion not included in the CPD's initial press release on the incident: Any mention of "MAGA supporters" or any mention of the race of the alleged assailants. Police clarified that they had not received any official information backing TMZ reporter Charles Latibeaudiere's claim, which he attributed to sources close to Smollett, that the alleged attackers shouted, "This is MAGA country."

Nor had the police corroborated that the attackers were white, since Smollett had told them their faces and hands were both covered. After launching a search for surveillance video and potential witnesses, the police department reported late Tuesday that "thus far we have not found anything to be able to put out a description."

I was told that public records requests for the incident report may take "weeks" to be approved. I was also told the Chicago police remain in charge of investigating the alleged incident, while the FBI probe of the alleged hate mail remains separate

CPD's public information office also told me late Tuesday that when police responded to the 911 call regarding the incident, Smollett gave them no details about where it occurred or what the attackers looked like. None. They were reportedly on scene for an hour with Smollett. When I asked again how the claims about white "MAGA attackers" were disseminated in the press, the PIO replied:

"We have no idea where that came from."

Minutes after I hung up the phone with her, a local Chicago reporter tweeted that Smollett did mention the "MAGA" angle in a "follow-up, supplemental interview." Which is it?

Despite all the holes, contradictions and unanswered questions, the MAGA hate crime narrative has already calcified. (Sound familiar?) By 5 p.m. Eastern on Tuesday, a search for "MAGA" and "Smollett" on Google yielded 3,520,000 results. And TMZ ended its day of social justice pot-stirring with the Rev. Al Sharpton calling for President Donald Trump to "denounce Jussie Smollett's MAGA attackers" who have yet to be identified.

Classic manufactured "news:" Report on an uncorroborated hate crime. Plant unverified details. Repeatedly blame white male Trump supporters. Stoke Hollywood outrage. Enlist the godfather of hate crime hoaxes to call on the president to denounce phantom attackers. Reap clicks and publicity. Indict all skeptics as racists and haters. Repeat.

Smears first. Facts later. How much deader can American journalism get?

title: Latest Entertainment News: Priyanka Chopra on â€˜Wild Wild Countryâ€™ Film; â€˜Manikarnikaâ€™ Clash Continues
â€˜This is MAGA Countryâ€™: Actor Jussie Smollett Attacked by Trump Supporters in Chicago Hate Crime
text:
â€” from Alternet

Actor/singer Jussie Smollett, best known for his portrayal of musician Jamal Lyon on the Fox series â€œEmpire,â€ has been the victim of an apparent hate crime in Chicagoâ€”and the suspects, TMZ is reporting, told him, â€œThis is MAGA country.â€

The 36-year-old actor, who is African-American and openly gay, had arrived in Chicago from New York City late Monday night and went to a Subway to get something to eat. After leaving that Subway, according to TMZ, Smollett was attacked by two white men who wore ski masks and used racial and anti-gay slurs.

The assailants, TMZ reports, beat Smollett, poured bleach on him, put a rope around his neck and declared, â€œThis is MAGA countryâ€ as they were leaving. MAGA is short for â€œMake America Great Again,â€ which was President Donald Trumpâ€™s 2016 campaign slogan.

Although Smollett suffered a broken rib, he was well enough to be discharged from Chicagoâ€™s Northwestern Hospital on Tuesday morning, January 29.

Smollett had been the subject of racial threats before the incident, which Chicago police are investigating. ThatGrapeJuice.Net has posted a note that was sent to Foxâ€™s Chicago studio and told Smollett, â€œYou will die, black f****râ€; according to TMZâ€™s sources, the letter was sent more than a week ago.

Smollett was cast as Jamal Lyon, a gay R&B singer, in 2014â€”and he came out as gay during an interview with Ellen DeGeneres in March 2015. The Northern California native is known for his recording career as well as his acting, and Smollettâ€™s album, Sum of My Music, was released in 2018.

title: â€˜Presume everyone WEARS A WIREâ€™ â€” â€˜NO-TOUCHINGâ€™ rule â€” SMALL-TIME developer's BIG ROLE in probe
text:
â€˜Presume everyone WEARS A WIREâ€™ â€” â€˜NO-TOUCHINGâ€™ rule â€” SMALL-TIME developer's BIG ROLE in probe Presented by Facebook

Happy subzero Wednesday, Illinois. I know youâ€™re all in bed reading todayâ€™s PLAYBOOK. Stay there. We just beat the record low for this day at minus 19. Story here

THE BUZZ

After winning the war against ex-Gov. Bruce Rauner and entering into what should be the golden days of his career, House Speaker Mike Madigan saw his name dragged into the corruption case against Ald. Ed. Burke.

Advertisement

According to Tuesdayâ€™s Sun-Times bombshell report, the FBI secretly recorded Madigan talking about his private law firm during a meeting with Ald. Danny Solis and a hotel developer looking to build in Chinatown. Madigan is not charged with any wrongdoing. And in a statement, he said, â€œTo my knowledge, I am not under investigation by the office of the U.S. attorney, and I have not been contacted by the U.S. attorney relative to Dan Solis.â€

State lawmakers I talked to were taking a wait-and-see approach to the story â€” itâ€˜s an eyebrow-raising revelation but itâ€™s still doesnâ€™t mean anything without a charge. â€œHeâ€™s a lawyer trying to get business for his private law firm. Thatâ€™s what lawyers do,â€ said one state representative, echoing what many Springfield legislators had to say. Gov. J.B. Pritzker said he had no opinion on the news (Sun-Times story here ). More than a few lawmakers acknowledged having mentally retraced their own conversations with Madiganâ€”just as many did when the Sun-Times revealed Solis turned mole. â€œItâ€™s a reminder that you just presume everyone wears a wire,â€ said another lawmaker.

You donâ€™t have to tell that to Madigan. In all his years, heâ€™s never been charged with wrongdoing (the same canâ€™t be said for Burke, for example). Madigan is careful about drawing the lineâ€”maybe right to the edgeâ€”between political work and private practice. Madiganâ€™s also cautious about how he communicates. He doesnâ€™t use a cell phone unless he borrows someone elseâ€™s.

Madigan was a no-show at the speakerâ€™s podium Tuesday for Day One of the General Assembly. Spokesman Steve Brown told POLITICO the speaker was working in his office, meeting with lawmakers and getting committee assignments nailed down. It was a day that should have been heralded as a new beginning in state government. That was the case across the hall in the state Senate, where Pritzker showed up to celebrate the new session.

On the House side, there was neither fanfare nor a gubernatorial visit. Majority Leader Greg Harris led lawmakers in a debate about the Rules. Then came an announcement that the House would adjourn until next week due to cold weather. The Senate, meanwhile, is in session today.

MORE BUZZ

Lawmakers yesterday took part in sexual harassment training that was described as intense. It prompted chatter all day long about whatâ€™s appropriate in the comfy confines of the Capitol. Itâ€™s not OK, for example, to greet colleagues with a hug or kiss without their permission. The no-touching rule touched off a debate among lawmakers who see their colleagues as friends. For some, a hug and peck on the cheek are how you say hello. A woman legislator, though, said it really shouldnâ€™t be so difficult to say â€œDo you mind if I hug you?â€ The discussion was moderated by an investigator for the Illinois Department of Human Rights, according to one attendee.

Fresham Democratic Rep. Anne Stava-Murray, who has been a lightning rod on the issue, attended the training and took part in discussions. â€œIt was worth it to be the voice in the room that said the things that needed to be said,â€ she told POLITICO. Stava-Murray previously said she was â€œforcibly kissedâ€ by a lawmaker at a gathering for freshman legislators. Tuesdayâ€™s sexual harassment training was instituted after the #MeToo movement hit the statehouse. Among some incidents: Tim Mapes, former chief of staff to Mike Madigan, was fired after a state employee accused him of sexual harassment.

Welcome to POLITICOâ€™s Illinois Playbook. Have a tip, event, announcement, endorsement? Send to [email protected]. SUBSCRIBE to Illinois Playbook: http://politi.co/1NTMQid

BURKE FALLOUT

â€” Small-time developer plays big role in corruption probe, reports Sun-Timesâ€™ By Mark Brown, Fran Spielman, Tim Novak and Jon Seidel. See Y. Wong was a small-time developer with big dreams for reshaping Chinatown until his ambitious projects hit the skids in the last real estate recession. Several projects failed. Investors lost their money. Lawsuits piled up, and some of Wongâ€™s activities came to the attention of federal authorities. Story here

â€” Chuy Garcia â€˜shockedâ€™ over Solis details; may not endorse in mayoral race: Rep. Jesus "Chuy" Garcia (D-Ill.) told the Sun-Timesâ€™ Lynn Sweet he was "shocked" about details in a court affidavit concerning retiring Ald. Danny Solis and why he cooperated with federal investigators. â€œThereâ€™s a lot of personal stuff. Itâ€™s â€” everything is pretty bizarre," Garcia said. "The greatest concern should be political corruption, of course, something that Iâ€™ve stood against since I delved into politics." Story here

â€” Solis resigns as Zoning czar: Ald. Danny Solis (25th) has resigned as chairman of the City Councilâ€™s Zoning Committee, but for now remains a member of the City Council, Mayor Rahm Emanuelâ€™s office announced Tuesday. Sun-Times Fran Spielman has the story here

â€” Solisâ€™ personal finances are under scrutiny, too. Since 2004, he has paid himself more than $330,000 from his campaign fund for â€œservices renderedâ€ or â€œcontractualâ€ work, according to Illinois State Board of Elections records. Tribuneâ€™s Hal Dardick, Jason Meisner and David Heinzmann report. Story here

CAMPAIGNS

â€” More calls for reform: Chicago aldermen and mayoral candidates continued pushing Tuesday for the kinds of government reforms they say Chicagoans are clamoring for in the wake of a federal public corruption investigation at City Hall. By Tribuneâ€™s John Byrne and Greg Pratt. Story here

â€” New ads from Preckwinkle, Chico: Mayoral candidates with money to spare are ramping up their ad campaigns. Toni Preckwinkleâ€™s latest digital ad is an attack piece targeting Susana Mendoza. It features old video of Mendoza as a state legislator describing her then-support for the death penalty, complete with inflammatory language. Ad here And Gery Chico is out with a new ad that highlights his history with Chicago Public Schoolsâ€”as a student and later as CPS president. Ad here

â€” Lightfoot endorsements: Three aldermanic candidates are endorsing mayoral candidate Lori Lightfootâ€”and sheâ€™s endorsing them. Katie Sieracki, 33rd Ward aldermanic candidate (who faces incumbent Ald. Deb Mell); Marianne Lalonde, 46th Ward aldermanic candidate (facing incumbent Ald. James Cappleman); and Andrew Rowlas, 50th Ward aldermanic candidate (facing incumbent Ald. Debra Silverstein).

â€” Daley dynasty is a blessing and a curse in the crowded race to become Chicagoâ€™s mayor, reports Bloombergâ€™s John McCormick. â€œA lot of my progressive friends, who have no business experience, I think are unrealistic about stuff that they think about business," Daley said. "So, Iâ€™m unabashedly pro-business for the future of this city." Story here

â€” Two former friends take on Ald. Roderick Sawyer. A former cop and a former accountant aim to unseat the 6th Ward alderman, writes Block Clubâ€™s Jamie Nesbitt Golden. Story here

â€” Mayoral candidates making corruption a campaign issue. Paul Vallas came out with his broom yesterday, saying itâ€™s time to clean house. Lori Lightfoot called for an investigation into the Zoning Department under Solis. And Garry McCarthy encouraged investigators to â€œdig deeper.â€

â€” Chicago elections board not ready for hackers or natural disaster, City Hall watchdog finds: The cityâ€™s elections board is unprepared to protect the integrity of the polls should disaster strike, according to a wide-ranging audit of the agencyâ€™s operations. Inspector General Joseph Fergusonâ€™s report warns the board hasnâ€™t conducted employee performance reviews in at least a decade, hasnâ€™t fixed its financial woes and is rife with technological vulnerabilities. The Tribune's Todd Lighty has the story here .

THE JUICE

Itâ€™s been a while since we tracked the big money going in to the mayoral campaigns. Here are the most notable donations and who gave them during the past 10 days.

Bill Daley received $100,000 from Ilan Shalit of Consolidated Trading. Shalit donated $50,000 to Mayor Rahm Emanuel last year before he dropped out of the race. Madison Dearborn Partners co-founder Paul Finnegan ($100,000), venture capital exec Bryan Cressey ($25,000)â€”Cressey was an early partner of private-equity firm GTCR that also included Bruce Raunerâ€”and Bandon Dunes Golf Resort developer Michael Keiser ($10,000).

Susana Mendoza: Regional Council of Carpenters PAC ($100,000), attorney Bob Clifford ($10,000), attorney Adam Hoeflich ($10,000), attorney Joseph Power ($25,000) and CKL Engineers CEO Mae Whiteside ($15,000).

Paul Vallas: billionaire poultry producer Joseph Grendys ($100,000).

Lori Lightfoot: ad agency CEO Dale Taylor ($25,000).

Jerry Joyce: Heâ€™s received $368,000 in loans from his pediatrician wife, Jannine Joyce.

In the hedging your bet category: Wheels fleet management CEO Jim Frank gave $25,000 each to Mendoza and Daley.

DELEGATION

Lipinski v. Newman redux? Democrat Marie Newman, who came close to defeating Rep. Dan Lipinski, D-Ill., in the 2018 primary, was in Washington, D.C., on Tuesday, and told the Sun-Timesâ€™ Lynn Sweet that she was exploring another run against him. â€œI did launch a formal exploratory a couple weeks ago,â€ Newman said. Story here

CHICAGO

â€” Study: A third of young adults want out of Chicago; ill omen for population loss, by Sun-Times' Maudlyne Ihejirika: "Over a third of young adults in Chicago â€” especially African Americans â€” want out of this city, citing racism, fractured police-community relations, neighborhood disinvestment and lack of jobs and economic mobility, a new study finds. The University of Chicagoâ€™s GenForward Project surveyed African-American, Asian, Latinx and white young adults from 10 diverse neighborhoods, and found 36 percent want to leave the city â€” but as high as 46 percent in challenged neighborhoods like Englewood." Story here

â€” Report of assault on 'Empire' actor Jussie Smollett, by Tribuneâ€™s Tracy Swartz and William Lee. Chicago police detectives on Tuesday reviewed â€œhundreds of hoursâ€ of footage from city and private cameras in the Streeterville neighborhood, but did not gain leads on a report of a â€œpossible racially-charged assault and batteryâ€ involving a star of the television show â€œEmpire.â€ Police said they had not made arrests in the reported attack on Jussie Smollett, who plays Jamal Lyon on Fox's â€œEmpire.â€ Story here

â€” Storm impact: Chicago cancels another day of classes; union publishes list of educator grievances, by Chalkbeatâ€™s Cassie Walker Burke. â€œThe parents and principal shoveled the sidewalks because Sodexo didnâ€™t show up on time, parking lot was not plowed,â€ reads one anonymous complaint. Story here

â€” Other property tax firms to benefit from the Burke/Madigan fallout. Crainâ€™s reports. Story here

â€” Chicagoâ€™s 10 coldest days ever recorded. Tribune has details here





FROM THE GOVERNOR'S OFFICE

â€” Gov. J.B. Pritzker has been meeting with legislators. It's a good way for him to get to know people one on one and gives lawmakers an opportunity to offer their two cents, according to a lawmaker who had an appointment.

STATE

â€” Lawsuit says racial harassment is â€˜standard operating procedureâ€™ at U of I. The lawsuit filed Monday in federal court includes numerous allegations of racial harassment of black employees at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. The suit says black employees at the school were â€œexposed to threats of racial violence, such as nooses, swastikas, KKK garb, racist graffiti, and confederate flags.â€ Illinois Public Media's Lee Gaines and Christine Herman report. Story here

â€” Can Pritzker, Foxx deliver on criminal justice reforms? Chicago Reporterâ€™s Curtis Black reports. Story here

LEGISLATION

â€” Police required to provide 3 phone calls to arrestees under new proposal: Cook County Board President Toni Preckwinkle, county Public Defender Amy Campanelli and others unveiled proposed legislation at a Tuesday press conference that would require police to let arrestees make three phone calls within an hour of their detention. The bill, sponsored by state Reps. Theresa Mah and Justin Slaughter, would clarify the current state requirement that people be given an opportunity to call family or an attorney within a "reasonable" time of their arrest.. WBEZ's Miles Bryan has the story here

NATION

â€” Big border deal fades before talks even begin, by POLITICO's Rachael Bade and Burgess Everett: Story here

â€” U.S. intelligence chief breaks with Trump on North Korea, Iran, ISIS, by POLITICOâ€™s Rebecca Morin and Nahal Toosi: Story here

â€” Stacey Abrams to give Democratic response to State of the Union, by POLITICO's Marianne LeVine: Story here

â€” Is Trump really winning over Hispanics? by POLITICO's Gabby Orr: Story here

MEDIA MATTERS

â€” How the R. Kelly investigation began. The New York Times's Ben Sisario profiles Chicago music journalist Jim DeRogatis, who spent nearly 20 years investigating allegations against R. Kelly--long before many in the media followed up. Story here

â€” All in the family. ABC/7 newsroom has family ties to three politicians. Robert Feder has the story here

BIRTHDAYS

Outgoing Ald. Ricardo Munoz, POLITICO National Reporter Natasha Korecki.

WHERE'S RAHM

No public events.

title: The Manure-Spreaders of Media Sensationalism
text:
Right Opinion The Manure-Spreaders of Media Sensationalism

Here we go again. If you think the manure-spreaders of sensationalism who masquerade as ethical practitioners of journalism learned anything from last weekâ€™s MAGA-bashing Covington Catholic High School hoax, I have three words for you:

Ha, ha, ha.

On Tuesday morning, uncorroborated claims by actor Jussie Smollett that he was the victim of a â€œbrutalâ€ hate crime by Trump supporters in Chicago went viral across social media. Entertainment rag TMZ.com first splashed â€œexclusiveâ€ headlines that the â€œEmpireâ€ cast member was â€œbeaten by MAGA backersâ€ in a â€œhomophobic attackâ€ at around 2 a.m. in Chicago. If you have no idea what â€œEmpireâ€ is or who Smollett is, join the club. The TV star is apparently a vocal critic of Trump and attacked â€œ45 and all his white hooded cohortsâ€ on Instagram last week.

But I digress.

Within minutes, the gossip siteâ€™s squib on the TV starâ€™s alleged victimization trended on Twitter and rocketed up to USA Today, Variety, CBS, CNN and The New York Times. The Fishwrap of Record breathlessly reported lurid details of two people who â€œwrapped rope around his neck,â€ which multiple outlets characterized as a â€œnoose.â€ A police statement providing incident background stated that â€œthe offenders began to batter the victim with their hands about the face and poured an unknown chemical substance on the victim,â€ according to Smollett. Multiple websites reported that the substance was bleach.

This is truly horrible, if true. But color me cautious and skeptical. TMZ initially reported that Smollett had exited a Subway chain restaurant near his luxury apartment when accosted by the racist, homophobic assailants, who allegedly recognized him from his work on â€œEmpire.â€ Allegedly, Smollett received a hate mail with the word â€œMAGAâ€ on it addressed to him and sent to his studio in Chicago last week. If this was a premeditated attack, the FBI should get to the bottom of it.

But oddities and discrepancies abound:

TMZ quoted one of the â€œMAGA countryâ€ attackers who allegedly hurled epithets at Smollett: â€œArenâ€™t you that fâ€”-t â€˜Empireâ€™ nâ€”â€“?â€

Question: How many racist homophobic menaces wander around the upscale Streeterville neighborhood of liberal Chicago at 2 a.m. carrying rope and bleach, yelling about â€œMAGA countryâ€?

Question: How many racist homophobic menaces have ever heard of â€œEmpire,â€ could recognize Jussie Smollett, or know or care anything about his sexuality?

Despite TMZâ€™s claim that Smollett had the â€œhell beat outta himâ€ and attackers â€œbroke his ribsâ€ plus subjected him to a chemical attack, an ambulance was not called and he instead â€œself-transportedâ€ to the hospital. CWB Chicago, a local public safety watchdog site, reported on police dispatch records documenting that Smollettâ€™s friend â€œFrankâ€ refused EMS services for Smollett; no mention of bleach was made; â€œno or minor injuryâ€ was observed; and â€œofficers never sent a â€˜flash; message with offender descriptions to field units.â€

Weird.

Another assertion not included in the CPDâ€™s initial press release on the incident: Any mention of â€œMAGA supportersâ€ or any mention of the race of the alleged assailants. Police clarified that they had not received any official information backing TMZ reporter Charles Latibeaudiereâ€™s claim, which he attributed to sources close to Smollett, that the alleged attackers shouted, â€œThis is MAGA country.â€

Nor had the police corroborated that the attackers were white, since Smollett had told them their faces and hands were both covered. After launching a search for surveillance video and potential witnesses, the police department reported late Tuesday that â€œthus far we have not found anything to be able to put out a description.â€

I was told that public records requests for the incident report may take â€œweeksâ€ to be approved. I was also told the Chicago police remain in charge of investigating the alleged incident, while the FBI probe of the alleged hate mail remains separate

CPDâ€™s public information office also told me late Tuesday that when police responded to the 911 call regarding the incident, Smollett gave them no details about where it occurred or what the attackers looked like. None. They were reportedly on scene for an hour with Smollett. When I asked again how the claims about white â€œMAGA attackersâ€ were disseminated in the press, the PIO replied:

â€œWe have no idea where that came from.â€

Minutes after I hung up the phone with her, a local Chicago reporter tweeted that Smollett did mention the â€œMAGAâ€ angle in a â€œfollow-up, supplemental interview.â€ Which is it?

Despite all the holes, contradictions and unanswered questions, the MAGA hate crime narrative has already calcified. (Sound familiar?) By 5 p.m. Eastern on Tuesday, a search for â€œMAGAâ€ and â€œSmollettâ€ on Google yielded 3,520,000 results. And TMZ ended its day of social justice pot-stirring with the Rev. Al Sharpton calling for President Donald Trump to â€œdenounce Jussie Smollettâ€™s MAGA attackersâ€ who have yet to be identified.

Classic manufactured â€œnews:â€ Report on an uncorroborated hate crime. Plant unverified details. Repeatedly blame white male Trump supporters. Stoke Hollywood outrage. Enlist the godfather of hate crime hoaxes to call on the president to denounce phantom attackers. Reap clicks and publicity. Indict all skeptics as racists and haters. Repeat.

Smears first. Facts later. How much deader can American journalism get?

title: Janet Jackson lands Glastonbury Festival headlining slot
text:
NEWS Janet Jackson lands Glastonbury Festival headlining slot Newsdesk Share with :





Janet Jackson has reportedly landed a headlining slot at this year's Glastonbury Festival.



According to Britain's The Sun newspaper, Janet will be taking to the stage at Worthy Farm in Somerset, England as part of the country's iconic music festival.



If the reports are true, it would be the 52-year-old singer's first-ever Glastonbury performance.



"Janet is relaunching her career in a major way this year and she thought this would be the perfect opportunity," a source told the publication. "She has never performed at Glastonbury but she knows what a massive deal it is.



"It is looking like she will perform on Sunday but her exact slot is to be confirmed. Organisers are still booking acts and arranging the schedule but she is really excited to be back."



Janet has yet to comment on the rumours on her social media pages. She did, however, send her love to Empire star Jussie Smollett on Tuesday (29Jan19), sharing a picture of the pair together after news broke that he'd been attacked in a suspected hate crime in Chicago.



"Sending u my love," Janet wrote, alongside purple heart and praying hands emojis.



Other stars confirmed to be playing the 2019 Glastonbury Festival include Janelle Monae, Stormzy and Kylie Minogue.



"I'm so thrilled to announce that I'll be playing the 'Legend slot' on Sunday 30th June at @GlastoFest 2019," Kylie wrote on Twitter last year (18). "It will be 14 years since I was originally meant to appear there and so much has happened up to now. I can't wait to see you all there to share this special show."



The 50-year-old had been scheduled to headline the iconic festival in 2005 but was forced to pull out a month beforehand as she battled breast cancer, and was subsequently replaced by Basement Jaxx. The Australian star was declared cancer-free in early 2006.



The 2019 Glastonbury Festival runs from 26 to 30 June.

title: Priyanka Chopra and Nick Jonas show support after alleged hate crime against actor Jussie Smollett
text: American actor Jussie Smollett , popularly known for his TV series 'Empire', was attacked in Chicago on Tuesday by two men who hurled racial and homophobic slurs at him before punching him and wrapped a rope around his neck in a possible hate crime attack. The 35-year-old openly gay actor was later hospitalized following the early morning attack. The attackers also poured an unknown chemical substance on him. The actor-singer was reportedly in the city for a scheduled Saturday concert.Reports suggest the two men shouted â€œThis is Maga countryâ€ after putting a noose around his neck and pouring bleach on him. title: "Empire" actor Jussie Smollett had noose around his neck when officers arrived, police say
text:
Police are investigating a possible hate crime against "Empire" actor Jussie Smollett who claimed he was attacked on a Chicago street by two men who wrapped a rope around his neck and yelled racial and homophobic slurs.

The FBI is also involved in the case, but so far investigators have been unable to put out a description of the suspects, reports CBS News' Dean Reynolds.

Smollett, who plays a gay musician on the hit Fox show "Empire," and identifies as gay in real life, said he was beaten by two masked men who shouted racist epithets, gay slurs, and put a noose around his neck. A police dispatcher had the barest of details on the early morning attack, which was reported by Smollett's business manager.



"Regarding a friend who was assaulted and battered â€¦ he's supposed to be well-known â€¦ a noose was placed around the friend's neck," the dispatcher said.



When police got to his apartment, they said a noose was still around Smollett's neck. He told them he was also doused with an unknown chemical and officers said they smelled bleach on his clothes.

In a now-deleted Instagram post by "Empire" co-creator Lee Daniels, Smollett appeared to have an abrasion on his cheek. Daniels said, "You didn't deserve, nor anybody deserves, to have a noose put around your neck, to have bleach thrown on you."

Police said in a subsequent meeting, Smollett added his assailants referenced President Trump's campaign slogan â€“ "make America great again" â€“ during the attack.

Twelve detectives and a number of FBI agents are now investigating what has been classified as a possible hate crime. But sources said they have seen security video of Smollett outdoors early Tuesday morning and nothing of an assault. Detectives have expanded the search area for video of the alleged assailants but haven't found any footage or witnesses.



Smollett's "Empire" co-star Vivica A. Fox tweeted, "I'm so angry and hurt about this!" California Senator Kamala Harris, a 2020 presidential candidate, called the attack "an attempted modern day lynching."

In a statement, 20th Century Fox Television and Fox Entertainment said it was "deeply saddened and outraged" by the "despicable act of violence and hate." After the attack, Smollett went to the hospital, where he was evaluated and released.
