title: LGBTQ+ Hate Crimes Are on the Rise â€” In Numbers and Severity
text:
On Tuesday morning, news broke that Empire actor Jussie Smollett had been hospitalized after two people physically assaulted the actor, fractured his rib, tied a noose around his neck, and poured bleach on him. In a statement, the Chicago Police Department confirmed that they are investigating the incident as a â€œpossible hate crime.â€

After the assault, the New York City Anti-Violence Project released a statement emphasizing that â€œJussie is not aloneâ€ in his experience. Gay Black men are among â€œsome of the most vulnerable to violence in the LGBTQ community.â€

And the data backs up NYCAVPâ€™s statement. According to the latest numbers from the FBI, the number of hate crimes reported nationwide rose from 6,121 in 2016 to 7,175 in 2017. The most common types of hate crime incidents were based on the victimâ€™s race (59.6%), religion (20.6%), and sexual orientation (15.8%). Of the 7,175 hate crimes reported, 7,106 were single-bias incidents while 69 were based on more than one bias.

The FBI defines a hate crime as a "criminal offence against a person or property motivated in whole or in part by an offender's bias against a race, religion, disability, sexual orientation, ethnicity, gender, or gender identity.â€

NYCAVPâ€™s 2017 report on hate violence also showed a disturbing trend for LGBTQ people who experience violence. While the FBIâ€™s hate crimes report comes from data culled from law enforcement agencies, NYCAVPâ€™s report is comprised of data collected at nationwide anti-violence programs and LGBTQ people who report hate violence to the AVP.

AVPâ€™s annual report cited a 20% decrease in reported hate violence, meaning that fewer people have reported their experiences to AVP, not that there were fewer hate-motivated crimes. In a statement to Out, AVP said that the â€œnormalization of hate violenceâ€ could be behind the decrease in reporting.

â€œPeople may be less inclined to report less severe incidents as they become a regular occurrence,â€ the organization wrote. â€œThat does not mean violence against LGBTQ people itself is lessening. On the contrary, in that same year we saw the highest amount of anti-LGBTQ hate movitated homicides in over twenty years of tracking hate violence against LGBTQ people.â€

While the number of hate crimes reported to AVP has gone down, the crimes that were reported were more severe. In 2017, AVP recorded 52 hate violence related homicides, the highest number ever recorded in 21 years of data collection and an 86% increase from 2017. Of those victims, 71% were people of color, 52% were trans or gender nonconforming and 40% were trans women of color. The number of homicides of LGBTQ cisgender men increased 400% from 2016 (4 incidents) to 2017 (20 reported homicides).

The rates of violence crimes involving weapons, sustained injuries and requiring medical attention increased, as well. Forty-six percent of LGBTQ people who experienced hate violence sustained an injury (up from 31% in 2016), 42% sought medical attention (up from 23% in 2016) and 27% reported that their attackers used weapons (up from 13% in 2016).

While Smollett said he does not know his attackers, that is actually outside the norm for LGBTQ+ people who experience violence. According to NYCAVP, 57% of LGBTQ people who experience hate violence know the person who causes them harm, usually a co-worker (22%), a relative or family member (21%) or a landlord or neighbor (20%). Hate crimes most often happen in a personâ€™s private residence (29%) or workplace (24%).

If you or someone you know has experienced harassment or assault, you can report it to AVP on its website or by calling (212) 714-1141.

NARRATOR VOICE: THEY ALREADY HAVE. Media Shouldnâ€™t Make The Same Mistakes in Empire Actor Jussie Smollett Attack Stories As The Mistakes They Made With The Covington Kids.

Robby Soave at Reason posted a huge scoop on this developing story earlier today: â€œAccording to the victim, the offendersâ€™ faces were concealed,â€ a police spokesperson told Reason. â€œWe have no record indicating that [they shouted â€˜MAGAâ€™], we only have record of them shouting racial and homophobic slurs at him.â€ Chicago police have also released a statement contradicting claims that Smollett identified his attackersâ€™ race and heard them shout â€œMAGA.â€ â€œWe have no record of The MAGA Country comment,â€ said the police in a statement. â€œWe have racial and homophobic comments documented.â€ Even without a MAGA shouting/white guys component to this story, what Smollett â€“ who has reportedly already been discharged from the hospital â€“ said happened to him is absolutely horrific. If the story is accurate, the perps should absolutely be punished to the fullest extent of the law. However, in the mad dash to get to the bottom of the allegations in order find out what happened and who committed the alleged acts, the national press needs to keep itself in check on this and have all their facts in order before rushing to social media to report on what theyâ€™ve found out.

Hence, the 48 Hour Rule: â€œSo, the Covington Kerfuffle erupting over Saturday evening and Sunday morning initially earned one of those â€˜mehâ€™ reactions: another pearl-clutching media reaction over something simple and stupid, if not actually fraudulentâ€¦ So â€“ IAW (in accordance with) sensible practice, I deferred any interest, personal reaction or comment for at least 48 hours. The first reports about anything are usually wrong, misleading, inaccurate; SOMETHING has happened, and it usually takes at least that long for reporters to put out the fire in their hair and come up with some sensible reportage. Such was, I assumed (over considerable evidence to the contrary, gleaned through sad experience over the years) the common practice also among the more responsible news-gathering organizations. It seems that I am doomed to disappointment again, on this front.â€

Not in the era of clickbait and Twitter, sadly. But then, the DNC-MSM has long described itself as â€œthe first draft of history.â€ But as any writer can tell you, first drafts invariably suck. Thatâ€™s why, in a more cautious era, they got edited, polished, and fact checked before publication.
